newsitem.title: VATICAN: Carey said "very pleased" with Pope meeting.
newsitem.headline: Carey said "very pleased" with Pope meeting.

text.p: Archbishop of Canterbury George Carey prayed before the tomb of St Peter on Wednesday and pronounced his first official meeting with Pope John Paul a success in their difficult dialogue on Christian unity.
"He told us he was very pleased (with the meeting)," Canon Jim Rosenthal, director of communications for the Anglican Communion, told Reuters as Carey toured St Peter's Basilica.
The spiritual head of the 70 million member Anglican Communion visited Christendom's largest church the day after his first official meeting with the Pope.
They met unofficially in 1992 during a visit that was made tense by Carey's criticism before his arrival in Rome of the Roman Catholic ban on contraception.
Carey, accompanied by his wife Eileen, knelt to pray before what archaeologists believe is the burial place of St Peter, the first Pope, directly under the basilica's main altar.

The Anglican leader also visited the crypt where modern popes are buried. He stopped before the tomb of Pope Paul VI, whose 1963-1978 reign coincided with the start of a Catholic-Anglican dialogue after more than four centuries.
The churches split in 1534 when England's King Henry VIII broke with Rome over papal authority. They remain divided over the issue and recently hit a stumbling block over women priests.
At the end of Tuesday's meeting, the Pope, Carey and other prelates in the Anglican delegation delivered a group blessing.
"Also, we expect your blessing for Rome," the Pope told Carey in an impromptu remark. The future course of relations will be a topic of talks at an official audience on Thursday.
In formal speeches, both emphasised the drive for unity.

"Our churches bear the marks of separation and division," Carey told the Pope. "We cannot undo overnight doctrinal differences and the bitternesses that have resulted from the legacy of history but we are able to confront them as fellow Christians..."

Carey became Anglican leader in 1990. Two years later the Church of England, mother church of Anglicanism, voted to allow women priests in a move that severely tested relations between Canterbury and Rome. The first were ordained in 1994.

The 76-year-old Polish Pope, who prayed with then Anglican leader Robert Runcie during a historic 1982 visit to Canterbury, told Carey that Anglicans and Catholics had not ceased to be brothers and sisters in God despite differences.
"The task before us is to strengthen that bond, until we reach the full unity that is Christ's will for us," he said.
On Tuesday night Carey worshipped at Rome's Episcopalian church with Cecilia Monge Teran De Erazo, the first woman to be ordained an Anglican priest in Italy's capital.
The Catholic Church says it does not have the authority to allow women to become priests because Christ chose only men as his apostles and was therefore reflecting "divine will".
Because of their opposition to women priests, a handful of Anglican bishops, more than 300 clergy and thousands of lay members have converted to Catholicism.
Recognition of the Pope's supreme authority over any unified Christian Church, or Papal primacy, has been another thorny issue testing the Catholic-Anglican dialogue.
The Pope said in a 1995 encyclical that for the sake of unity he was willing to seek an accommodation with other Christian denominations on the future role of the papacy.
